intro: Selinum wilhelmsii, commonly known as the Chilean parsley, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in mountainous regions. Its aromatic leaves are used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb.
